comment: This is called the English Opening. It usually leads to a postional struggle.
One of many possible replies. Black prepares for ... d5.
The game has now transposed into a Queen's Gambit Declined. This position could have been arrived at by 1. d4 d5 2. c4 e6 3. Nc3

moves: 1. c4 e6 2. Nc3 d5 3. d4 Nf6 4. cxd5
comment: The exchange variation. White's goal is now to move up his two queenside pawns and exchange them leaving Black with a weak pawn.

moves: 1. c4 e6 2. Nc3 d5 3. d4 Nf6 4. cxd5 exd5 5. Bg5
comment: Pinning the knight and threatening 6. Bxf6 and Black would have to recapture with the pawn because 6... Qxf6 loses to 7. Nxd5.

moves: 1. c4 e6 2. Nc3 d5 3. d4 Nf6 4. cxd5 exd5 5. Bg5 Be7
comment: Breaking the pin.

moves: 1. c4 e6 2. Nc3 d5 3. d4 Nf6 4. cxd5 exd5 5. Bg5 Be7 6. e3 Nbd7
comment: It is important not to play ... Nc6 blocking the c pawn.

moves: 1. c4 e6 2. Nc3 d5 3. d4 Nf6 4. cxd5 exd5 5. Bg5 Be7 6. e3 Nbd7 7. Nf3
comment: White is continuing normal development.

moves: 1. c4 e6 2. Nc3 d5 3. d4 Nf6 4. cxd5 exd5 5. Bg5 Be7 6. e3 Nbd7 7. Nf3 c6 8. Bd3 O-O 9. Qc2
comment: White will soon begin attacking on the queenside.

moves: 1. c4 e6 2. Nc3 d5 3. d4 Nf6 4. cxd5 exd5 5. Bg5 Be7 6. e3 Nbd7 7. Nf3 c6 8. Bd3 O-O 9. Qc2 Re8
comment: Black will move the knight on d7 to f8 so that the bishop on c8 can be developed.

moves: 1. c4 e6 2. Nc3 d5 3. d4 Nf6 4. cxd5 exd5 5. Bg5 Be7 6. e3 Nbd7 7. Nf3 c6 8. Bd3 O-O 9. Qc2 Re8 10. O-O Nf8 11. h3 Be6 12. Rfc1
comment: Moving the rook to the half-open file. White plans to place his other rook on b1 to support the pawn advance.

moves: 1. c4 e6 2. Nc3 d5 3. d4 Nf6 4. cxd5 exd5 5. Bg5 Be7 6. e3 Nbd7 7. Nf3 c6 8. Bd3 O-O 9. Qc2 Re8 10. O-O Nf8 11. h3 Be6 12. Rfc1 N6d7
comment: Black hopes to simplify by exchanging bishops.

moves: 1. c4 e6 2. Nc3 d5 3. d4 Nf6 4. cxd5 exd5 5. Bg5 Be7 6. e3 Nbd7 7. Nf3 c6 8. Bd3 O-O 9. Qc2 Re8 10. O-O Nf8 11. h3 Be6 12. Rfc1 N6d7 13. Bf4
comment: White prefers not to exchange.

moves: 1. c4 e6 2. Nc3 d5 3. d4 Nf6 4. cxd5 exd5 5. Bg5 Be7 6. e3 Nbd7 7. Nf3 c6 8. Bd3 O-O 9. Qc2 Re8 10. O-O Nf8 11. h3 Be6 12. Rfc1 N6d7 13. Bf4 Nb6
comment: So that Black can play 14... Bd6 and the queen will protect the bishop.

moves: 1. c4 e6 2. Nc3 d5 3. d4 Nf6 4. cxd5 exd5 5. Bg5 Be7 6. e3 Nbd7 7. Nf3 c6 8. Bd3 O-O 9. Qc2 Re8 10. O-O Nf8 11. h3 Be6 12. Rfc1 N6d7 13. Bf4 Nb6 14. Rab1
comment: Preparing for an eventual b4

moves: 1. c4 e6 2. Nc3 d5 3. d4 Nf6 4. cxd5 exd5 5. Bg5 Be7 6. e3 Nbd7 7. Nf3 c6 8. Bd3 O-O 9. Qc2 Re8 10. O-O Nf8 11. h3 Be6 12. Rfc1 N6d7 13. Bf4 Nb6 14. Rab1 Bd6 15. Ne2 Ng6 16. Bxd6 Qxd6 17. a4
comment: White does not play b4 at once because Black can answer with Nc5 with an equal game.

moves: 1. c4 e6 2. Nc3 d5 3. d4 Nf6 4. cxd5 exd5 5. Bg5 Be7 6. e3 Nbd7 7. Nf3 c6 8. Bd3 O-O 9. Qc2 Re8 10. O-O Nf8 11. h3 Be6 12. Rfc1 N6d7 13. Bf4 Nb6 14. Rab1 Bd6 15. Ne2 Ng6 16. Bxd6 Qxd6 17. a4 Rac8 18. Qc5
comment: White would have a positional advantage after 18... Qxc5 19. dxc5 Nd7 (Not 19... Nxa4 20. b3 trapping the knight) 20. b4

moves: 1. c4 e6 2. Nc3 d5 3. d4 Nf6 4. cxd5 exd5 5. Bg5 Be7 6. e3 Nbd7 7. Nf3 c6 8. Bd3 O-O 9. Qc2 Re8 10. O-O Nf8 11. h3 Be6 12. Rfc1 N6d7 13. Bf4 Nb6 14. Rab1 Bd6 15. Ne2 Ng6 16. Bxd6 Qxd6 17. a4 Rac8 18. Qc5 Qb8 19. Qa3
comment: Now the a pawn must be protected.

moves: 1. c4 e6 2. Nc3 d5 3. d4 Nf6 4. cxd5 exd5 5. Bg5 Be7 6. e3 Nbd7 7. Nf3 c6 8. Bd3 O-O 9. Qc2 Re8 10. O-O Nf8 11. h3 Be6 12. Rfc1 N6d7 13. Bf4 Nb6 14. Rab1 Bd6 15. Ne2 Ng6 16. Bxd6 Qxd6 17. a4 Rac8 18. Qc5 Qb8 19. Qa3 a6 20. Rc3
comment: White is going to double rooks on the c file.

moves: 1. c4 e6 2. Nc3 d5 3. d4 Nf6 4. cxd5 exd5 5. Bg5 Be7 6. e3 Nbd7 7. Nf3 c6 8. Bd3 O-O 9. Qc2 Re8 10. O-O Nf8 11. h3 Be6 12. Rfc1 N6d7 13. Bf4 Nb6 14. Rab1 Bd6 15. Ne2 Ng6 16. Bxd6 Qxd6 17. a4 Rac8 18. Qc5 Qb8 19. Qa3 a6 20. Rc3 Qc7 21. Rbc1 Ra8 22. Nd2
comment: The knight will eventually make its way to c5.

moves: 1. c4 e6 2. Nc3 d5 3. d4 Nf6 4. cxd5 exd5 5. Bg5 Be7 6. e3 Nbd7 7. Nf3 c6 8. Bd3 O-O 9. Qc2 Re8 10. O-O Nf8 11. h3 Be6 12. Rfc1 N6d7 13. Bf4 Nb6 14. Rab1 Bd6 15. Ne2 Ng6 16. Bxd6 Qxd6 17. a4 Rac8 18. Qc5 Qb8 19. Qa3 a6 20. Rc3 Qc7 21. Rbc1 Ra8 22. Nd2 a5
comment: So that if 23. b4 axb4 24. Qxb4 Rxa4

moves: 1. c4 e6 2. Nc3 d5 3. d4 Nf6 4. cxd5 exd5 5. Bg5 Be7 6. e3 Nbd7 7. Nf3 c6 8. Bd3 O-O 9. Qc2 Re8 10. O-O Nf8 11. h3 Be6 12. Rfc1 N6d7 13. Bf4 Nb6 14. Rab1 Bd6 15. Ne2 Ng6 16. Bxd6 Qxd6 17. a4 Rac8 18. Qc5 Qb8 19. Qa3 a6 20. Rc3 Qc7 21. Rbc1 Ra8 22. Nd2 a5 23. Rb1 Nc8
comment: White's pieces are much more coordinated than Black's.

moves: 1. c4 e6 2. Nc3 d5 3. d4 Nf6 4. cxd5 exd5 5. Bg5 Be7 6. e3 Nbd7 7. Nf3 c6 8. Bd3 O-O 9. Qc2 Re8 10. O-O Nf8 11. h3 Be6 12. Rfc1 N6d7 13. Bf4 Nb6 14. Rab1 Bd6 15. Ne2 Ng6 16. Bxd6 Qxd6 17. a4 Rac8 18. Qc5 Qb8 19. Qa3 a6 20. Rc3 Qc7 21. Rbc1 Ra8 22. Nd2 a5 23. Rb1 Nc8 24. b4
comment: If White can trade this pawn for Black's pawn on a4 and then trade his a pawn for Black's pawn on b7, Black will be left with a weak pawn on c6. This is the plan initiated on move four of the game!

moves: 1. c4 e6 2. Nc3 d5 3. d4 Nf6 4. cxd5 exd5 5. Bg5 Be7 6. e3 Nbd7 7. Nf3 c6 8. Bd3 O-O 9. Qc2 Re8 10. O-O Nf8 11. h3 Be6 12. Rfc1 N6d7 13. Bf4 Nb6 14. Rab1 Bd6 15. Ne2 Ng6 16. Bxd6 Qxd6 17. a4 Rac8 18. Qc5 Qb8 19. Qa3 a6 20. Rc3 Qc7 21. Rbc1 Ra8 22. Nd2 a5 23. Rb1 Nc8 24. b4 axb4 25. Qxb4 Nd6 26. Nb3
comment: Supports the advance of the a pawn and prepares for an eventual Nc5.

moves: 1. c4 e6 2. Nc3 d5 3. d4 Nf6 4. cxd5 exd5 5. Bg5 Be7 6. e3 Nbd7 7. Nf3 c6 8. Bd3 O-O 9. Qc2 Re8 10. O-O Nf8 11. h3 Be6 12. Rfc1 N6d7 13. Bf4 Nb6 14. Rab1 Bd6 15. Ne2 Ng6 16. comment: According to plan.

moves: 1. c4 e6 2. Nc3 d5 3. d4 Nf6 4. cxd5 exd5 5. Bg5 Be7 6. e3 Nbd7 7. Nf3 c6 8. Bd3 O-O 9. Qc2 Re8 10. O-O Nf8 11. h3 Be6 12. Rfc1 N6d7 13. Bf4 Nb6 14. Rab1 Bd6 15. Ne2 Ng6 16. comment: Black intends 28... Bf5

moves: 1. c4 e6 2. Nc3 d5 3. d4 Nf6 4. cxd5 exd5 5. Bg5 Be7 6. e3 Nbd7 7. Nf3 c6 8. Bd3 O-O 9. Qc2 Re8 10. O-O Nf8 11. h3 Be6 12. Rfc1 N6d7 13. Bf4 Nb6 14. Rab1 Bd6 15. Ne2 Ng6 16. comment: Black is beginning a kingside counterattack. In retrospect, it would have been better to simplify the position with 29... Nef5 since the kingside attack never materializes and the h pawn becomes a target.

moves: 1. c4 e6 2. Nc3 d5 3. d4 Nf6 4. cxd5 exd5 5. Bg5 Be7 6. e3 Nbd7 7. Nf3 c6 8. Bd3 O-O 9. Qc2 Re8 10. O-O Nf8 11. h3 Be6 12. Rfc1 N6d7 13. Bf4 Nb6 14. Rab1 Bd6 15. Ne2 Ng6 16. comment: Black has gained some space on the kingside.

comment: The bishop is needed to support the advance of the pawn to a6.

comment: A nicely posted piece.

Be2 Ne4 33. Nc5 Nxc5 34. Qxc5 Be6 35. Nd2 Nf5 36. Nf3 Qd8 37. a6 bxa6 38. Rxa6 Rxa6 39. Bxa6 Qa8 40. Qxc6 Qxc6 41. Rxc6 Ra8 42. Bd3
comment: and Black resigned. There is no way to prevent the threat of 43. Bxf5 and 44. Nxh4 winning a second pawn. If 42... Ra1+ 43. Kh2 Ra2 then White simply plays 44. Rc2 and the pawn on h4 cannot be saved
